bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, March 12, 1950

div1.p: Kean refers Hench to some letters from Sternberg to Reed and to Chaille, and comments on developments resulting from the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, March 12, 1950
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
Sunday, 12 March '50
Dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
We were so pleased to get
your radio talk on ACJH and
Cortizone and the inclosed letter
of Dr. R.J. Gill to you announcing
the award to you and to Dr. Ken-
dall of the Passano Award. It
is a handsome sum too. There are
very few as liberal. Cornelia,
(who is now entirely whole and
hearty - even her stomach ulcer
is now quiessent) thinks that I
should return Dr. Gill's letter.
I tell her if you wanted it returned
you would have marked that on
2
the letter. I have not been in a
hurry to congratulate you because
I knew that you were terribly busy
and might not have time to read
such casual letters as I would
write. But a day or two ago I
was looking over old papers and
I came across two letter-press
copies of letters of Gen. Sternberg
keep them
which I thought might interest you.
One is written to Major Reed after he
had completed his experiments at
Camp Lazear, or rather some of
them. The other to Prof Chaille at
Tulane Univ. was written two years
earlier where the Y. F. experts had
no doubt of the contagious ness of
fomites. You see he tells Reed that
3
he has no doubt that the mosquito
is the usual way of conveying the
infection, but is not sure that it is
the only way. Gorgas however, who
was in Havana and saw Reed's
cases, doubted if the mosquito was
the only way, or even the usual way.
He told me this, and was honest
enough to put it on record in his
final report. Neither one of these letters mentioned
the infected bedding experiments,
which were of enormous economic
as well as epidemilogical importance.
They seem to have hit the blind
spot in Gorgas's eye, for you know
that in Havana Gorgas kept on burn-
ing or disinfecting bedding and
clothing for months after the Chief
Surgeon had forbidden this as unnecessary
This having been approved by the
Surgeon General before Gen. Wood
issued the order. I do not remem-
ber ever having seen any allusion
in Gorgas's writings to these experi-
ments. We had a call from Wm
Trevilian Turner, a cousin of mine
and a fine man, who is Chief of the
freight Div. of the So. R. R. He told us
a story of Dr Thomas Kavanaugh of Le
Gendre Building New Orleans, La.
which Cornelia is anxious that I should
repeat to you. It is of a friend of their
wife of an Army Officer stationed
in Vienna, Austria. She was ill of
arthritis (rheumatic). She went to a
famous doctor there who cured her.
When they were ordered home the doctor
gave her a supply of the medicine for
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
future attacks, and if she needed
more the name of a doctor in
New York who could get the prescrip-
tion filled. Dr. Kavanaugh has
cured other patients with this pre-
scription. You can write to Dr.
Kavanaugh if you see fit and
have time. Mrs. Gen. Frank
McCoy wants to meet you and
Cornelia would like when you
next come to Wash. That you would
let her know in advance so she
could arrange to have you & the
McCoys at lunch or dinner.
The pointed slip about the bill in
Congress for an appropriation of $350,-
000. For eulogizing Walter Reed's work
and giving a program of things to be
done, leaves me a little cold. I feel
sure there is some one behind it who
6
has gotten up the program and
expects to have the spending of the
money. He may write to you about
it. Rep. Bland of Va. has recently
died. It reminds me of a remark
in the Kalends “When a politician tells
you of a plan by which you can get
something for nothing, you may be
sure that he will get the something.
and you will get the nothing”.
This letter is already too long. So
I will stop here with our good wishes
to you and Mrs Hench.
